data.title: Thomas Mansfield Potts (1677-1754)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Thomas Potts born 1677 Chesterfield, Derbyshire, England died 1754 Bordentown, Burlington, New Jersey including ancestors + descendants + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors

[sibling(s) unknown]

Descendants

Profile last modified 5 Jul 2022 | Created 12 Mar 2011

This page has been accessed 2,139 times.

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Death and Legacy

1.2 Slaves

2 Sources

Biography

Judge Thomas Potts Jr. was baptized on 30 December 1677 at Chesterfield, Co. Derbyshire, England[1] and the next year was brought to America by his parents Thomas Potts and Joan Platts of "The Peak", Derbyshire, England.[2] [3]

When Thomas was 20 he married Mary (Records) Potts (abt.1678-) on 20 June 1698 in Burlington, Burlington, New Jersey. The couple had 5 children: Richard Potts, Rebecca Potts, Ann Potts, Thomas Potts, and Mary Potts.

The current profiles of their children Mary Potts and Nathaniel Potts (1710-1761) give the same DOB, 1710. Research needs to be done to see if they were possibly twins, and Mary "Records" died at this time. There is a 9 year gap between their birth and his next children Joshua Potts (1719-1761) and William Potts (1721-1783), likely by his wife Mary (Borden) Potts (abt.1684-abt.1741)

After the death of his 2nd wife Mary (Borden) Potts (abt.1684-abt.1741), he married Rebecca (Stacy) Potts, widow of Joshua Wright.

Thomas Potts Junior received a bequest in the 1715 will of his aunt Mary Revell.[4]

Death and Legacy

Thomas Potts of Mansfield, Burlington wrote his will 30 Jan 1754 naming wife Rebecca and children Nathaniel, Joshua, William, Ann (wife of William Folwell), Mary (wife of John Cox), grandchildren (children of daughter Rebecca Cox and Thomas Potts).[5]

Judge Thomas Potts Jr. died on 2 February 1754 at Burlington County, New Jersey, at age 76. He was buried at Baptist graveyard, Bordentown, New Jersey.

Slaves

""two negroes" are mentioned in the will abstract, names not stated.

Sources

↑ Vital Records of New Jersey, Vol. 22, p. 303.

↑ Peak District From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia [1]

↑ US and International Marriages: Thomas Mansfield Potts: Birth date: 1677 ; Marriage date: 1698

↑ Nelson, William (ed.), Calendar of Wills, Administrations, Etc. Volume I, 1670-1730. Documents Relating to the Colonial History of the State of New Jersey. Trenton, NJ: Archives of the State of New Jersey, 1901, volume 23, page 381

↑ Honeyman, A. Van Doren (ed.), Calendar of Wills, Administrations, Etc. Volume III, 1751-1760, Documents Relating to the Colonial History of the State of New Jersey. Trenton, NJ: Archives of the State of New Jersey, 1924, volume 32, page 257

See Also:

Historical collections relating to the Potts family in Great Britain and America Authors; Potts, Thomas Maxwell, b. 1836; Potts, William John, 1842-1895. Published; 1901. Thomas Potts, Jr., Page 134 #3.” (cont. on pgs 138, 144-145)
